message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Vancomycin binds the dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala, which is essential for bacterial cell wall synthesis. Penicillin and chloramphenicol inhibit protein synthesis, and polymyxin B disrupts the bacterial cell membrane.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin binds to D-Ala-D-Ala and interferes with cell wall synthesis in bacteria. Penicillin interferes with peptidoglycan synthesis. Chloramphenicol binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit and inhibits protein synthesis. Polymyxin B disrupts the cell membrane.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Vancomycin binds to the dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala, which is found in bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin binds the dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala and disrupts bacterial cell wall synthesis, making it an effective treatment for bacterial infections. Penicillin disrupts bacterial cell wall synthesis through a different mechanism by binding to and inhibiting the enzyme that forms peptidoglycan cross-links. Chloramphenicol inhibits bacterial protein synthesis while Polymyxin B disrupts bacterial cell membranes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin binds to the dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala and inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis. Penicillin also interferes with bacterial cell wall synthesis but by a different mechanism. Chloramphenicol inhibits bacterial protein synthesis while Polymyxin B disrupts bacterial cell membranes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin works by binding to the dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala and disrupting cell wall synthesis in bacteria. None of the other options work in this manner.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin binds to the dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala in bacterial cell walls, preventing its proper incorporation into the cell wall and leading to bacterial death. The other options have different mechanisms of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin binds to the dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala and inhibits cell wall synthesis in bacteria. Penicillin inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins, Chloramphenicol binds to 50S ribosomal subunit, and Polymyxin B alters the bacterial cell membrane.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that binds the dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala of bacterial peptidoglycan, which makes it an effective treatment for bacterial infections. Penicillin inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by interfering with cross-linking of peptidoglycan, chloramphenicol inhibits bacterial protein synthesis, and polymyxin B disrupts bacterial cell membranes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vancomycin binds to the dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala, preventing cell wall synthesis in bacteria. Penicillin and chloramphenicol have different mechanisms of action, and polymyxin B acts on the cell membrane.
